children.name: fashionable
children.definition: /ˈfæʃənəbəl/  clothes, styles, places or activities that are fashionable are popular at the present time, but will probably only be popular for a short time:
examples: ▪ the store sells fashionable clothes at prices you can afford.
▪ a style of painting that was fashionable in the 1930s
▪ kate spent her summers in cape cod working in a fashionable resort.
▪ they recently opened a cafe on manhattan’s fashionable east side.

children.name: cool
children.definition: /kuːl/ spokeninformalsaid to show approval of something that is fashionable, interesting, or attractive -- used especially byyoungpeople:
examples: ▪ he was wearing these really cool sunglasses.
▪ many young people start smoking because they think it looks cool.

children.name: hot
children.definition: /hɒtǁhɑːt/ informalvery fashionable now:
examples: ▪ one of the hot young writers of the decade
▪ they’re supposed to be the hottest thing since the beatles.

children.name: trendy
children.definition: /ˈtrendi/ informalvery fashionable, often for a short time -- used especiallyhumorouslyor to showdisapproval:
examples: theo xu hướng
▪ a trendy street market in the centre of paris
▪ delgado predicts that blonde hair will become trendy this summer.
▪ trendy bars and restaurants are opening and inexpensive apartments in the area are getting hard to find.

children.name: stylish
children.definition: /ˈstaɪlɪʃ/  welldesigned, andattractivein a fashionable way:
examples: kiểu cách
▪ she was wearing a stylish black woollen dress.
▪ stylish modern furniture

children.name: chic
children.definition: /ʃiːk/  very fashionable in anexpensiveway, and showing a lot of good judgement about good style:
examples: thanh lịch
▪ they live in a chic apartment overlooking the seine.
▪ a chic restaurant in boston
▪ the east side of the city has become very chic in the past few years.

children.name: cult
children.definition: /kʌlt/  fashionable and only known about by a small group of people - use this especially about things orpeoplethat later become veryfamous:
examples: ▪ alex garland’s cult novel ‘the beach’ was later made into a film starring leonardo di caprio.
▪ 60s cult band the velvet underground
▪ frankie knuckles is a cult figure in dance music.

children.name: in
children.definition: /ɪn/ informalfashionable at the present time :
examples: mốt
▪ purple seems to be in this year.
be the in place
▪ gstaad is the in place to go skiing in winter.
the in thing to do
▪ cycling to work has become the in thing to do.

children.name: hip
children.definition: /hɪp/ informaldoing things or done according to the latest fashion:
examples: hợp thời, tân thời
▪ the south side is becoming a really hip place to live.
▪ i hate old people who dress like teenagers and think they’re hip.

children.name: happening
children.definition: /ˈhæpənɪŋ/ informalfashionable and exciting:
examples: ▪ in four to five years, this will be a happening film festival.
▪ the town’s ok, but not what you’d call a happening place.

children.name: style b1
children.definition: style the quality of being fashionable :
examples: young women interested in style rather than comfort
in/out of style
long skirts are back in style.
the classic black dress is alwaysinstyle.

children.name: be in fashion
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈfæʃən/  if clothes, music, places, or activities are in fashion, they are fashionable and popular with many people at the present time:
examples: hợp thời trang
▪ latin music is very much in fashion.
▪ surprisingly, flared trousers are in fashion again.
▪ country cottage furniture has been in fashion for a long time now.

children.name: be the fashion
children.definition: /biː ðə ˈfæʃən/  to be fashionable:
examples: là mốt
▪ i thought it looked ugly, but iris said white suits were the fashion so i tried it on.
be the fashion among somebody
▪ wearing coats hanging off one shoulder is the fashion among schoolchildren at the moment.

children.name: be the latest thing
children.definition: /be the in thing/biː ðə ˌleɪtst ˈθɪŋ, biː ði ˌɪn ˈθɪŋ/ informalto be the most recent and most popular fashion now:
examples: ▪ when i was growing up, the video game ‘pong’ was the latest thing.
▪ i know cigars are the in thing, but you’ll never see me smoke one.
be the latest thing in something
▪ herbert’s house looks like a factory , but it’s the latest thing in modern architecture.
be the in thing to do
▪ having a holiday in ibiza seems to be the in thing to do at the moment.

children.name: be in
children.definition: /biː ˈɪn/ informalto be fashionable at the present time: đang thịnh
examples: ▪ long skirts are in at the moment.

children.name: be all the rage
children.definition: /biː ˌɔːl ðə ˈreɪdʒ/  if something, especially an activity, is all the rage, it is very fashionable, and popular with a lot of people, especially for a short time:
examples: đang thịnh
▪ before the war, ragtime was all the rage in the dancehalls.
▪ buying a cabin in the mountains may be all the rage at the moment, but is it really a sound investment?

children.name: be in vogue
children.definition: /biː ɪn ˈvəʊg/  if something, especially a style of music, decoration, art etc, is in vogue, it is fashionable at that time with aparticulargroupof people:
examples: là mốt
▪ do you remember when new wave music was in vogue?
▪ his photographs, stark and sometimes shocking, are very much in vogue with young intellectuals.

children.name: be the height of fashion
children.definition: (= be very fashionable)with her short dress and high boots she was the height of fashion.

children.name: come into fashion
children.definition: /ˌkʌm ɪntə ˈfæʃən/
examples: thành mốt, trở nên thịnh
▪ when did baseball caps come into fashion?
▪ when mini-skirts first came into fashion, women said they’d never wear them.
come back into fashion
▪ short haircuts for men went out for a time, and then they came back into fashion.

children.name: come in
children.definition: /ˌkʌm ˈɪn/  to become fashionable, especially for ashortperiod of time:
examples: thành mốt, trở nên thịnh
▪ skateboarding first came in during the early 1980s.
▪ new fashions seem to come in and go out again much more quickly these days.

children.name: make a comeback
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk ə ˈkʌmbæk/  to become fashionable and popular again,afterhaving been unfashionable for a long period of time:
examples: thịnh trở lại
▪ who’d have thought platform soles would ever make a comeback?
▪ games like ‘ludo’ and ‘snakes and ladders’ are really making a comeback.

children.name: set the trend
children.definition: /ˌset ðə ˈtrend/  to make something that is new fashionable, by doing, using, or wearing it, so that a lot of people copy you:
examples: tạo nên xu hướng
▪ young backpackers set the trend, and now people of all ages are looking for cheap ways to travel around southeast asia.
set the trend of
▪ to save the planet we must set the trend of caring for the environment.

children.name: fashionable
children.definition: /ˈfæʃənəbəl/  someone who is fashionable wears fashionable clothes, owns fashionable things, and goes to fashionable places:
examples: hợp thời trang , sành điệu
▪ this is the latest style of hat worn by fashionable women in milan.
▪ i’ve never been very fashionable. i’d rather wear what feels comfortable.

children.name: trendy
children.definition: /ˈtrendi/ informalfashionable -- use this especially about someone who you thinktriestoohardto be fashionable:
examples: chạy theo mốt
▪ stylish south beach cafés filled with trendy young couples
▪ she only talks like that because she wants to sound trendy.

children.name: sophisticated
children.definition: /səˈfɪstɪkeɪtəd, səˈfɪstəkeɪtəd/  someone who is sophisticated knows a lot about fashionable things and feels confident about being with fashionable people:
examples: sành điệu
▪ a sophisticated woman whose friends included many rich and famous people
▪ a play that will appeal to a sophisticated audience

children.name: fashion victim
children.definition: /ˈfæʃən ˌvɪktm/  someone who wears clothes that are fashionable, but that make them looksilly:
examples: ▪ a new designer who will appeal to fashion victims everywhere

children.name: fashion
children.definition: /ˈfæʃən/  a style of clothes, hair, behaviour etc that is fashionable:
examples: mốt , thời trang
latest fashionthe newest styles of clothes
▪ i always find it hard to keep up with the latest fashions.
fashion in clothes/music etc
▪ changing fashions in popular musicfashion for doing something
▪ who started this fashion for wearing old army clothes?

children.name: trend
children.definition: /trend/  a way of doing something or a way of thinking that is becoming fashionable:
examples: xu hướng
▪ a lot of the students here don’t think for themselves, they just follow the latest trends.
trend in
▪ today we’ll be examining the latest trends in kitchen design

children.name: craze/fad
children.definition: /kreɪz, fæd/  a fashion, activity, type of music etc thatsuddenlybecomes very popular, but only remains popular for ashorttime:
examples: mốt nhất thời
▪ a new fitness craze from australia is rapidly catching on.
▪ to no one’s surprise, the macarena proved to be a short-lived fad.

children.name: the latest thing
children.definition: /ðə ˌleɪtst ˈθɪŋ/  the most fashionable and newest thing to do, wear, or have:
examples: kiểu mới nhất
▪ the latest thing is to wear only white clothes.
▪ no matter how expensive, he always has to do the latest thing.
the latest thing in
▪ i can remember when eight-track tapes were the latest thing in music.

children.name: vogue
children.definition: /vəʊg/  a style of music, clothes, art etc that is fashionable with a particulargroupofpeople:
examples: ▪ people’s fondness for wearing black and other dark colours was a vogue i never really liked.
▪ a vogue for the paintings of claude lorraine

children.name: style b1
children.definition: style a particular design or fashion for something such as clothes, hair, furniture etc:thời trang, mốt
examples: car styles have changed radically in the past 20 years.
a style consultant
i read the fashion pages in the newspapers to keep up with the latest styles.
traditional/modern style
the rooms are furnished in a modern style.

children.name: out of fashion
children.definition: /ˌaʊt əv ˈfæʃən/  no longer fashionable - use this especially aboutclothesandmusic:
examples: lỗi mốt, lỗi thời
▪ it seems like all the clothes i buy are out of fashion by the time i wear them.
go/fall out of fashion
▪ rock'n'roll began in the fifties and has never really gone out of fashion.

children.name: go out
children.definition: /ˌgəʊ ˈaʊt/  especially british to stop being fashionable:
examples: hết thời , lỗi thời
▪ jogging went out when it was found to be harmful for the joints.
▪ i can’t believe you’re wearing those shoes -- they went out years ago!

children.name: unfashionable
children.definition: /ʌnˈfæʃənəbəl/  not fashionable - use this especially about people’s ideas, beliefs, and way of life:
examples: lỗi thời, lỗi mốt
▪ she lives in an unfashionable part of west london.
▪ socialism became unfashionable after the collapse of the berlin wall.

children.name: uncool
children.definition: /ʌnˈkuːl/ spokeninformalnot fashionable, interesting, or attractive - used especially byyoungpeople:
examples: ▪ a really uncool place for a holidayit’s uncool to do something
▪ nowadays it’s considered very uncool to wear fur.

children.name: date
children.definition: /deɪt/  tograduallybecome unfashionable, and be replaced with more modern styles, methods, ideas etc:
examples: trở nên lỗi thời, lỗi mốt
▪ the trouble with high fashion clothes is that they date very quickly.
▪ certain styles of music will never date, and will always be popular.
dated[adjective] fashionable in the past but looking or seeming old-fashioned now::
▪ i loved that album when i bought it a few years ago but it sounds really dated today.
▪ the production was excellent but the costumes looked dated.
